No, one does not equal three in the usual sense of mathematical equations. The concept of the Trinity, which teaches that there is one God in three persons - the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit - is not a mathematical equation, but rather a description of the complex nature of the divine being as revealed in the Bible.

The doctrine of the Trinity affirms that there is one God who exists eternally and co-equally as three distinct persons who share the same divine essence or nature. While it may be difficult to understand how one God can be three distinct persons, the doctrine does not claim that one equals three in a mathematical sense. Instead, it asserts that the divine being is a complex unity that can be described in terms of three persons who are united in one divine essence.
